comments.content: These horses are Russian horses, have nothing to do with hiding in the desert and do not race. They started out as a gift from Peter the Great to Catherine the first as a very special gift to his Golden Lover! Akhal-Teke.From Turkanese mountain horses. Mixed in Arabian lines(mostly Polish) to build up endurance!

Did anyone even bother researching or did they just make this all up?! Because that‚Äôs at least 2-3 different horses, it‚Äôs breed... not ‚Äúrace‚Äù... and so many more inaccuracies... smh.

Wow that video shows three different horses, one of which is not an Akhal Teke  üòÇ  The only horse that‚Äôs Kambarbay is the one with the rosette braids. The Akhal Teke with the shaved mane is Ak Gez Geli, lovely horse, but by no means exemplary of the bre ... See More

What's  with the  neg comments??  It is a very beautiful  animal, either way.   Just enjoy the beauty of all race horses or any horse.
Horses have breeds, not races. They have hair, not fur...and I can't even stand to watch this because it was sub titled by a fool.
It's a breed, not a race. And horses have hair, not fur. If you're going to write and post about animals, learn some shit first.
I thought i had seen every breed of horse, i guess i didn't. And i grew up on a farm. We boarded horses. Lord i miss it and my horsie friends.

I wonder, being Yahshua lived in Israel which is surrounded by dessert, if this is like the horse He'll return on?!

Wikipedia The Akhal-Teke is a horse breed from Turkmenistan, where they are a national emblem. They have a reputation for speed and endurance, intelligence, and a distinctive metallic sheen. The shiny coat of palominos and buckskins led to their nickname "Golden Horses".

There is a reason these are so vivid. It's not just cirrus clouds like usual. This is diamond dust. Small ice platelets suspended in the air, completely surrounding the spectators. It's basically like fog, but it occurs when it's below freezing and is made of ice crystals instead of liquid water droplets.

I'm a weather photographer and storm chaser as well. I'm always looking for optical phenomena. Here's the best I've captured. Two parhelia "sundogs" a 22¬∞ halo, an upper tangent arc, and as I pan up, the icing on the cake..  A brilliant 46¬∞ circumzenithal arc like a multicolored smile in the sky. This is all thanks to the correct sun angle combined with a windswept cirrostratus cloud layer.
